full_conversation: Therapist: Hello, Mrs. Johnson. How are you feeling today?
Client: Oh, hello Dr. Smith. I'm... I'm a bit nervous, to be honest. I know we're going to talk about that night again, and it's never easy.
Therapist: That's understandable. Remember, you're safe here.
Client: Thank you. I'll try to keep that in mind. It's just... every time I think about it, my heart starts racing.
Therapist: Take a deep breath. You're doing great.

Client: Okay... okay. I was in my old house, the one I lived in before moving to assisted living. It was late, maybe around 11 PM. I was getting ready for bed, had just finished my nightly cup of tea...
Therapist: Good. Stay with that memory.

Client: I heard a noise. At first, I thought it was just the house settling, you know? But then there was another noise, louder this time. It sounded like... like glass breaking. I froze. I couldn't move. I just sat there in my armchair, my heart pounding so hard I thought it might burst out of my chest.
Therapist: You're doing well. Keep going.

Client: I... I wanted to call for help, but my phone was in the kitchen. I was trapped in the living room. I heard footsteps, heavy ones. A man's voice, rough and angry, saying something to someone else. There were at least two of them. I felt so helpless, so scared...
Therapist: It's okay to feel those emotions. You're safe now.
Client: I... I can't... It's too much. I feel like I'm back there again. My hands are shaking...
Therapist: Take a moment. Breathe. You're here with me.

Client: *deep breath* Okay... okay. I remember thinking about my late husband, wishing he was there to protect me. But he wasn't, and I felt so alone. The intruders, they came into the living room. I tried to make myself as small as possible in my chair, hoping they wouldn't see me in the dark.
Therapist: You're very brave. Keep going.

Client: One of them saw me. He yelled, "Hey! We've got company!" I was terrified. I thought... I thought they might kill me. The other one turned on the light, and I saw their faces. They were young, probably in their twenties. One had a tattoo on his neck, the other had a scar above his eye.
Therapist: You're doing great. These details are important.

Client: They started ransacking the place, throwing things around, demanding to know where I kept my valuables. I couldn't speak, I was so scared. One of them grabbed my arm, shook me hard. It hurt so much. I thought my arm would break. I started crying, begging them not to hurt me.
Therapist: It's okay. You're safe here. Continue when you're ready.

Client: I... I told them where my jewelry box was, where I kept some cash. They took everything. But it wasn't enough for them. They kept yelling, asking for more. I didn't have anything else to give them. I felt so helpless, so violated. My home, my safe place, it wasn't safe anymore.
Therapist: You're doing incredibly well. How are you feeling right now?
Client: I feel... drained. Scared. But also... I don't know. Maybe a little stronger? It's hard to explain.
Therapist: That's normal. You're processing difficult emotions.
Client: Thank you. It's still hard to talk about, but... maybe it's getting a little easier? I don't know. I just know I don't want to feel like a victim forever.
Therapist: That's a powerful realization. We'll work through this together.
Client: I appreciate that, Dr. Smith. I really do. It helps to know I'm not alone in this anymore.
Therapist: You're not. Let's end here for today. You did excellent work.
Client: Thank you. I'll see you next week.
